IMPAIR.deftext:
make worse, weaken, injure

To IMPAIR something is to make it worse, to do harm to it. The word often suggests damage that gradually increases.

“Smoking cigarettes will damage your lungs and IMPAIR your breathing.”

“His eyesight was IMPAIRED by reading in very dim light.”

“The scandal will IMPAIR their chances of winning the election.”

In the Pretest, many people choose destroy as the meaning of IMPAIR. When you IMPAIR something, you cause it some damage, but you do not destroy it.

SYNOPSIS.deftext:
a summary, outline

A SYNOPSIS is a short summary or outline, usually of the plot of a book, play, or movie.

“It was difficult to make an understandable SYNOPSIS of a book with so many characters doing so many different things.”

“According to the SYNOPSIS, the next act takes place in the living room.”

“The announcer gave a SYNOPSIS of the president’s speech and summarized the main ideas.”

“We hurriedly read through several SYNOPSES to prepare for the test.”

Usage: The plural form of SYNOPSIS is SYNOPSES.

BLISS.deftext:
joy, happiness, delight

BLISS is a state of complete happiness or great joy. It is a very strong word, and often refers to the joys of heaven.

“She was unhappy in life, but hoped for eternal BLISS after death.”

“When he fell in love, he realized he had never known such BLISS before.”

“Their years of perfect BLISS were ended when he became ill.”

BLISSFUL is the adjective from BLISS and means “full of or causing great happiness.” “BLISSFUL ignorance” is happiness resulting from a lack of knowledge of events or circumstances that could cause unhappiness.

“They lived in BLISSFUL ignorance of the great dangers that surrounded them.”

Other forms of the word: BLISSFUL, adj.

INFRINGE.deftext:
to break, violate; to encroach, trespass

To INFRINGE a rule, law, or agreement is to break it, to fail to obey it.

“He accused us of INFRINGING the contract we had signed with him.”

“They INFRINGED the treaty by sending troops into the other country.”

INFRINGE is often used with on or upon to mean “to break in upon,” to encroach.

“We must never INFRINGE upon the rights of others.” The noun form of INFRINGE is INFRINGEMENT, the act of violating or trespassing.

“He was accused of copyright infringement because he printed the photo in his book without getting the photographer’s authorization.”

Other forms of the word: INFRINGEMENT, n.

MICROBE.deftext:
a bacterium, germ

The prefix micro- means very small. It is used in the word microscope, which is an instrument that helps you to see very small objects. A MICROBE is a very small living creature, one that is invisible to the naked eye. The word is used especially about small living things that cause diseases.

“There are thousands of tiny MICROBES in the air we breathe.”

“The scientists tried to discover the MICROBE that was responsible for the mysterious deaths of the animals.”

The most commonly chosen incorrect answer is atom. An atom, of course, is a very small thing—in fact, far smaller than a MICROBE. The key difference is that a MICROBE is alive while an atom isn’t.

NONENTITY.deftext:
an unimportant person or thing

An ENTITY is something that exists. The basic meaning of NONENTITY is “something that does not really exist.” Usually, though, NONENTITY is used about a person who is so undistinguished and insignificant that it is as if he didn’t exist.

“Although he came from a famous family, he himself was a NONENTITY.”

“Everyone thought he was a complete NONENTITY, but then it turned out he was a prince in disguise.”

TREMULOUS.deftext:
quivering, trembling; timid, fearful

TREMULOUS is related to the word tremble. Someone or something that is TREMULOUS trembles or shakes.

“The old lady could not hold the cup of tea in her TREMULOUS hands.”

When used about a person, TREMULOUS sometimes suggests that the trembling is due to fear or nervousness.

“The boy TREMULOUSLY asked the girl if she would dance with him.”

Many people pick huge as the meaning of TREMULOUS. They are probably confusing TREMULOUS with tremendous, which sounds and looks very much like it.

VOID.deftext:
emptiness, vacancy

A VOID is an empty, unfilled space.

“He gazed into the limitless VOID of outer space.”

“There is an aching VOID in my heart since you left me.”

“The car plunged over the cliff and into the VOID.”

VOID is also an adjective, meaning empty, vacant. The word is usually found in the legal term, “null and VOID,” which means “having no legal force.”

“The judge declared that the contract was null and VOID.” VOID is also used in this sense as a verb, meaning to nullify.

“The judge VOIDED the contract.”

ASSAIL.deftext:
to attack, assault

To ASSAIL someone is to attack him, usually suddenly or repeatedly.

“The mob ASSAILED the soldiers with rocks and sticks.”

“He was ASSAILED by blows on the head as he tried to escape from the crowd.”

ASSAIL can be used in a general sense about any kind of attack.

“As soon as he started the project he was ASSAILED by doubts about whether it would be successful.”

An ASSAILANT is someone who attacks.

“Dick was beaten up in the alley by several unknown ASSAILANTS.”

Other forms of the word: ASSAILANT, n.

HYPOCRISY.deftext:
insincerity, deceit

HYPOCRISY comes from a Greek word meaning acting. Someone who practices HYPOCRISY acts good or virtuous when in reality he isn’t.

“I can’t believe his HYPOCRISY. He always talks about how wrong it is to lie, and he’s the worst liar I know.”

“The reporter exposed the HYPOCRISY of the religious leader who in private was a cruel and evil man.”

A HYPOCRITE is someone who pretends to be virtuous when he isn’t.

“They’re all HYPOCRITES who don’t practice what they preach.”

Vanity is a popular choice as the meaning of HYPOCRISY. Both vanity and HYPOCRISY are vices, but a person can have one fault without the other.

Other forms of the word: HYPOCRITE, n. HYPOCRITICAL, adj.

DESTITUTE.deftext:
extremely poor, needy; lacking, deprived

Someone who is DESTITUTE is absolutely penniless and lacks the basic necessities of life, such as food, clothing, and shelter.

“They had always been poor, but the fire left them homeless and completely DESTITUTE.”

“I have never been DESTITUTE, but I know what it’s like to go hungry.”

“When Mr. Jones died, his widow was left DESTITUTE.”

The phrase DESTITUTE of means lacking, not having, devoid.

“We could tell the tree was dying because it was completely DESTITUTE of leaves in the middle of the summer.”

“The cruel dictator was DESTITUTE of ordinary human feelings.”

ENDOW.deftext:
to provide, give

ENDOW means to give or provide something for the benefit of a person or an institution.

“The grateful parent ENDOWED a new wing in the hospital in his son’s name.”

“The school is looking for someone to ENDOW a new library.”

To be ENDOWED with something is to have it naturally.

“She is ENDOWED with a great talent for painting.”

“He was ENDOWED with the gift for making money.”

The noun form of ENDOW is ENDOWMENT, which means a gift, usually of money or property.

“Harvard College received an ENDOWMENT of several hundred books.”

Other forms of the word: ENDOWMENT, n.

IMBECILIC.deftext:
idiotic, weak-minded

An IMBECILE is an extremely weak-minded person, one who cannot develop mentally beyond the age of about seven. IMBECILIC is the adjective from IMBECILE, and means “like an IMBECILE.”

“His actions were so IMBECILIC that no one could believe he was an adult.”

“She said Bill’s ideas were IMBECILIC and not worth discussing.”

Other forms of the word: IMBECILE, n.

LOATH.deftext:
unwilling, reluctant, disinclined

LOATH means extremely unwilling, reluctant.

“He was LOATH to go.”

“They were LOATH to lend us any more money until we had paid back what we already owed.”

“I am LOATH to sign anything I haven’t read first.”

Do not confuse LOATH and loathe (pronounced (pronunciation). The verb loathe means to hate, to despise.

“I loathe having to get up early.”

LOATH has a similar meaning, but is only used as an adjective.

“He is LOATH to stay behind. He loathes being left out of anything.”

Usage: LOATH is also sometimes spelled loth.

THRONG.deftext:
a crowd, multitude

A THRONG is a great number of people crowded together.

“THRONGS of people came to see the hit movie.”

“The small child got lost in the THRONG at the parade.”

THRONG is also a verb, meaning to crowd together or to fill by crowding.

“People THRONGED into the street for the parade.”

“The park was THRONGED with people waiting to hear the concert.”

questions.prompt: Will eating poisoned food IMPAIR your health?
Does the SYNOPSIS of a book include every word?
Would most people like to have somebody INFRINGE upon their rights?
Is it difficult to see a MICROBE?
Would TREMULOUS handwriting be difficult to read?
Can a VOID be very large?
Are pigs ENDOWED with the ability to fly?
Would most people like to be called IMBECILIC?
Are children usually LOATH to eat ice cream?
He IMPAIRED the two of us and decided I was the better.
After reading the SYNOPSIS of the TV show in the newspaper, we decided not to watch it.
Their BLISSFUL marriage lasted over fifty years.
The truce between the countries was INFRINGED when enemy soldiers attacked our town.
The doctor examined the tissue under the microscope to try to spot the MICROBES.
The public relations man said he could take any NONENTITY and make him world famous in six weeks.
In a TREMULOUS voice he said he'd never been so scared in his entire life.
We built the biggest VOID in the city.
Police searched for the ASSAILANT who had attacked the man in broad daylight.
She felt it was HYPOCRISY to say you liked a person if you really didn't.
This program is terrible. The actors on it are completely DESTITUTE of talent.
We are ENDOWED with certain rights under our Constitution.
Everyone praised the play as being truly IMBECILIC.
The boss was LOATH to fire anyone just before Christmas.
THRONGS of people visited the museum for the display of Egyptian treasures.
